titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Began upon the 7th: Satire of Juvenal. Walk before and after dinner.— Evening at Dr: Brown’s. Mr Arbuthnot there— He goes for England, next week.

2. Weather rainy, great part of the day— I could only take a short walk— Met M. d’Aguilar— Went this Evening with Mrs: A. to the play— Saw Axur— Afterwards a short ride, and walk under the trees: which we found very damp.

3. A Rainy day again. Mr: Arbuthnot called upon us this afternoon.— Mrs: Adams went to Charlottenburg— I was caught by the rain in the park— Read Dryden’s preface to the translation of Juvenal publish’d by him—and a few letters of Zöllner’s tour into Silesia.
4. Independence day— Went to the play this Evening with Mrs: Adams— Saw an Opera, called Deception by Superstition— Walk’d afterwards, an hour under the trees.
5. Very busy all day in preparing a packet to go by Mr: Arbuthnot— He called upon us this afternoon. Walk this Evening in the park.

6. Sent the packet To Mr: Arbuthnot, who leaves this place to-morrow morning. Received letters and newspapers this evening from America— In the evening was at Dr: Brown’s— Mr: Arbuthnot and Mr Garlike were there.
7. Reading the papers and pamphlets from America— Long walk in the park this afternoon. Met, and walk’d with Mr: d’Aguilar— Afterwards at Dr: Brown’s— Garlike there.

8. Mr: Paleske called upon me this morning; upon his return from Dantzick— Dined at Count Haugwitz’s with a small company— The count promis’d to give me some letters for Silesia— General Beurnonville was there, and told me of his transactions in Holland; which I knew very well.— Rode with Mrs: A. to Treptow.

9. Weather excessively warm— Long walk in the park— Met Major Wartenberg.— Wrote a letter to my brother— Find the 7th: Satire of Juvenal harder to translate, and even to understand than either of the two I have done before.

10. Dined at Count Bünau’s, the Saxon Minister, with a company of about twenty persons. The minister Heinitz promised me some letters for Silesia— At the play this Evening— Saw the veil, a comedy, translated from the Italian.— Not remarkably good— Letter from Mr: Bourne.

11. I enter this day upon my thirty-fourth year— Went with Mr: Garlike to see a collection of prints and pictures— He dined with us, and spent the afternoon— Walk in the park— Mrs: Adams went to Charlottenburg, where she proposes to spend a few days.

12. Mrs: A. came into town this morning, and went out again to Charlottenburg before dinner— I called at Mr: Schickler’s compting house and transacted some business— Sent letters to America. Walk’d out, in the evening to Charlottenburg— Found the Minister Alvensleben there.— Had some music after supper— Dr: Brown was gone to town.

13. Return’d to Berlin this morning after breakfast— Met Mr: Paleske, who was going to Charlottenburg. Went there to dinner— Miss Esdorff dined there— In the afternoon we went to Mr: Cohen’s to see a play performed, as a welcome upon his return home from Holland— A work of Madame de Genlis, who likewise performed in it— The title is Galatée animée depuis 24 heures— A sequel to Rousseau’s Pygmalion— Very indifferent—preceded by a little scene called la cloison— In which a Lady holds a dialogue with her lover behind the partition— The spectators hear only what she says, and from that are to infer the lover’s part of the dialogue, which the lady is supposed to hear— We return’d after the play to Charlottenburg.

14. Came into town this morning before breakfast— M. d’Araujo called upon me, and Mr: Rosenstiel from Baron Heinitz— Took Mr: Garlike with me out to Charlottenburg to dinner— The Minister Alvensleben, and young Mr: Schickler there in the afternoon— We undertook to go to Grönewold but did not succeed— Play’d Chess with Mr: Garlike and Dr: Brown.

15. Came into town again before breakfast— Made up my letters— Visit to Mr: Paleske; at Mr: Schickler’s Counting house; to Count Haugwitz— Dined in the park at Richards’s—a picnic dinner: about fifty persons half of whom I did not know— Conversation with Bignon— Return’d to Charlottenburg in the evening.

16. Came to town before breakfast— Wet with the rain— Spent the forenoon in making preparations for our Journey— Went out to Charlottenburg to dinner. Mr: Tyrwhitt Secretary to the Prince of Wales and a member of Parliament; Mr: Garlike, and Mr: Schickler dined there.— After dinner Mr: Ditmar called there— He gave us several letters for Silesia; and came home with us— Found directions from Mr: Rosenstiel for our journey— Garlike called upon me.

17. We had ordered our horses at 2 o’clock in the morning, and set out at half past three— Rode all day, and at 9. this Evening arrived at Frankfurt upon the Oder.— The road is indifferent and sandy almost the whole way: The distance ten german miles and a quarter. We lodge at the sign of the three crowns.

18. We found here the remnant of the annual fair, from which we met yesterday a great number of Jews, returning to Berlin.— Went this afternoon to deliver Mr: Ditmar’s letter to professor Schneider; but he was not at home.— He came however soon after with another professor, who has been into Silesia, and who gave us several directions for our journey— They say there is nothing worth seeing at the University here.

19. Wrote to Mr: Welch. Professor Hulmans called upon us in the morning, and again in the afternoon. Went with us over the bridge, to see the monument erected to Prince Leopold of Brunswic.— It has nothing remarkable— We went likewise to a vineyard near the town, which commands a pleasant prospect— Wrote in the evening— Walking out before dinner we met Mr: Schneider; who walk’d with us.— Receiv’d a letter from Mr: Welsh.

20. Mr: Schneider called upon me this forenoon, and I walk’d with him to the baths, which are just at the gate of the town. We went likewise to a Gentleman’s house upon a hill from which we had an extensive prospect— After dinner we were to have gone to Lossow a village about three miles out of town but were disappointed of procuring a carriage and horses for the purpose— Walk’d again in the afternoon with Mr: Hulmann, & afterwards with Mrs: Adams.— The weather cold and unpleasant.

21. Walk this forenoon with Mrs: A— and caught in two showers of rain— Mr: Hüllman called upon us, at half past four in the afternoon, and we went to Lossow; a seat of Mr: Schoening the Landrath of the circle— The views of the river and the country beyond it from the neighbourhood of the house are pleasant, but the weather would not allow us fully to enjoy them— Return’d, between 8 and 9. in the evening.

22. The packet for which we waited, arrived from Berlin at about noon, and at one we left Frankfurt, for Grünberg. We rode almost all night, and reached Crossen at half-past one in the morning. Found the roads very bad, and the weather was unpleasant—cold and rainy— Better weather however, for travelling through these sands than if it were very warm and fair. Mr: Hüllman, called upon us this morning to take leave of us— We are indebted to him for many civilities and attentions.

23. At seven this morning we left Crossen, and after going through four miles more of sand, at about one afternoon reach’d Grünberg, the first Silesian town.— After dining I delivered my letter to Mr: Anders the town-director, who went with us to see Mr: Förster’s cloth manufactory: we after wards went upon an hill near the town, which commands a very extensive prospect; but from the rainy and foggy weather we could not fully enjoy it— Mr: Anders called this evening at our lodgings, and gave me a Berlin almanac for 1796, which contains a description of the Silesian mountains.

24. Before nine this morning we quitted Grünberg, and came three miles to Freystadt; in order to return to the great road to Hirschberg, from which we parted at Crossen. We arrived between 1. and 2.— Upon going to deliver my letter to Count Kalkreuth, I found he was absent, and not expected to return, this fortnight. We had ordered our horses for to-morrow morning, and it was probable we could not get them sooner. Besides which Mrs: Adams was very unwell, so that we could not think of proceeding further this day. Took a walk round the town, and saw several potteries, and cloth weavers— A member of the town council came in the name of the magistrates to compliment us upon our arrival, and offer us their services— He afterwards sent us some fruit— Mrs: A. being better, towards evening, we look’d over count Kalkreuth’s house and garden— The last has nothing remarkable— The house is a palace, handsomely furnish’d, principally with english furniture. There are many handsome drawings, statues, and prints. Among the rest those of the Luxembourg gallery by Rubens, and those of the Shakespear gallery.

25. A little before eight this morning, we left Freystadt, and arrived at Sprotau at 11. Waited three hours there for horses. Walked round the town— Mrs: A— went to see the convent of Nuns— We look’d over the church— Came from Sprotau to Bunzlau, five miles at one stage. Reach’d Bunzlau at 10 in the evening. At about half-way had the first sight of the Silesian mountains.

26. Visited the carpenter Jacob, and saw his machine representing the passion of Jesus Christ;— the weaver Hüttig, and saw his geographical and astronomical machines— A pottery, and saw the great pot— The orphan house, and saw the chapel and dining hall— Left Buntzlau, just after 12 at noon, and came through Löwenberg to Hirschberg—6 miles—fine turn-pike road. Arrived between 10 and 11. at night. Went to three houses before we could find a lodging. Got one at last at the three crowns.

27. Procured a better lodging at the black eagle just out of the gates of the town— Wrote all the forenoon. Went to the catholic church after dinner— Afterwards took a walk to see the town from without— Beautiful prospects. In the evening at the play, which was very much crowded.— Rübenzahl, an Opera, performed for the first time. The actors and singers bad— Music of the play good.

28. The post-master of the town came, and told us that he had been informed by Mr: Rosenstiel of our intended visit here; and offered us his services— In the afternoon we went with him and his family, to the Helicon, the Elysian fields, and the world’s end— My letters to my brother form my detailed journal for the present.

29. Went with the Post-master, in the forenoon to Mr: Schäffer’s, one of the principal linen merchants in the town; in the afternoon to the Cavalier-berg, and Castel-nuovo.— In the evening, at the post-master’s who has a pretty collection of pictures and of prints.
30. Went to Warmbrünn—the Kynast—Mr: Preller’s vitriol-works—with him to the Kochel-fall; and finally to Schreibershau.
31. Rode in a cart to the Glass houses on the frontiers—the Silesian at Hoffnungsand the Bohemian at Neuewelt, or Neuwald— Our driver hurt himself.— Return’d to Schreibershau at about 10 at night.
Day. Nothing regular, while we are travelling.
